text: I'm Matt gross the frugal traveler for
the new york times this summer I'm
embarking on the grand tour of Europe
over 12 weeks I'll seek out ancient
history and contemporary culture I'll
find cool hotels and eat memorable meals
and I'll stretch the US dollar to the
breaking point as soon as I saw a map of
Cyprus a guitar-shaped Puerto Rico sized
island in the eastern Mediterranean I
knew exactly what I had to do like a
mountaineer pining for the peak I had to
reach the very very tip of the car paws
Peninsula I thought of it as a
pilgrimage and like a good pilgrim I
would do it by the most frugal means
possible by hitchhiking but you can't go
hitching unprepared so I brought a tiny
LED flashlight a pocket knife and
multi-tool partly for protection partly
to open bottles of whatever I might come
across and of course some music to keep
me busy on the side of the road hi one
thing that wasn't optional with a
passport once a british colony cyprus
was divided politically in 1974 after
years of turmoil between Greek Cypriots
and Turkish Cypriot now the south is run
by Greeks the north by Turks thank you
once over on the Turkish side I needed
one last piece of equipment a good map
so I stopped in the issue crook store
and made some quick friends which what's
your name cake Dugan I left without a
map but with something more important a
ride to famagusta I was glad for the
lift but curious about why etha and
Zarah were going with famagusta in the
first place because we had visited this
area just after the war and you know now
that I'm here I'm curious to see how its
development when we arrived I had one
last question for them so do you
normally give rides to strangers they
look like they are nice people then they
drove off and left me in the old city of
Famagusta it's a pretty place with old
gothic churches venetian ruins and
reminders of the past everywhere you
look but I wasn't ready to rest I wanted
to check out the Salamis ruin a 2000
year old Roman city but hitching a ride
inside comma gusta was impossible so I
had to take a taxi I paid 13 lira or
about ten dollars for the 15-minute ride
but I got into the ruins free of charge
we are in a city that is establishment
more or less like 2,000 years ago so in
an amazing amazing place for a concert
we are very happy to make conscious here
what's the concert tonight is ms ever
done on a party time 1000
after the concert I got my first real
hitch with two Media Studies instructors
for the local university I think this is
the safest place for hitchhiking because
there is no public transportation so we
are used to take people
she wasn't kidding the next day I got a
ton of ride Nikki zero didn't speak much
English but he bought me an iced coffee
and pointed out the sights as we drove
from famagusta to Baz sip on the bus Oh
st. Barnabas over there and then I was
back on the shoulder somewhere above the
town of KU yaala where i got lunch and
some more hitchhiking advice if you
smile making people because they can't
believe people sometimes did they bagon
state so it's smiling face o.o is my
friend let me see your hitchhiking face
yeah I do this I don't know if I was
following his advice or not but over the
next two days I come ride after ride
after ride we're now heading off towards
the very tip of the peninsula about two
miles from the end however we stopped to
visit the Acosta's andreas monastery
this is a greek orthodox monastery when
turkey invaded cyprus in 1974 the Greeks
way out here in car paws had nowhere to
run to so they stayed the monastery is
famous threat Cyprus been healing power
of its waters from the monastery I
walked the remaining two miles to the
very end of the island and lost the
memory card that I recorded the video on
this cell phone pic is the only proof I
made it so my luck may have failed me
when it came to high technologies but it
held out for the hitchhiking these guys
dropped me off at Golden Beach where I
played in the water for a little while
then ran into reef at a Cypriot engineer
who invited me to a BBQ with his friends
are you going to come with us I would
like to but I'm worried that it might be
as it gets later it'll be difficult to
get back to dip car pile
we will even then come back as ref I put
it Americans socialized run drinks Turks
socialize around me the food was amazing
especially because it was given to me
for no other reason than sheer
hospitality but as we started packing up
I was worried the Sun was setting and by
the time or fat dropped me off it was
dark not many cars out now would I
really make it home to the Oasis
of course I would in Northern Cyprus all
you need is a thumb and a smile the
locals will do the rest tsutomu Gaskin
the New York Times done Matt gross
